statements.name: PROC DTREE
statements.description: The DTREE procedure in SAS/OR software is an interactive procedure for decision analysis. The procedure interprets a decision problem represented in SAS data sets, finds the optimal decisions, and plots on a line printer or a graphics device the decision tree showing the optimal decisions. â€  To use PROC DTREE you first construct a decision model to represent your problem. This model, called a generic decision tree model, is made up of stages.* Every stage has a stage name, which identifies the stage, as well as a type, which specifies the type of the stage. There are three types of stages: decision stages, chance stages, and end stages. In addition, every stage has possible outcomes.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains appropriate Annotate variables.

arguments.name: AUTOSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should rescale the probabilities of events for a given chance stage if the total probability of this stage is not equal to 1.

arguments.name: CBEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for all links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: CLINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for all links in the decision tree diagram except those that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: Specifies that the decision tree diagram should be drawn on one physical page.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Indicates the decision criterion to be used for determining the optimal decision and the certain equivalent for replacing uncertainties.
arguments.help: CRITERION=MAXEV | MINEV | MAXMLV | MINMLV | MAXCE | MINCE

arguments.name: MAXEV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: expected value

arguments.name: MINEV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: expected value

arguments.name: MAXMLV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: value with largest probability

arguments.name: MINMLV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: value with largest probability

arguments.name: MAXCE
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: certain equivalent value of expected utility

arguments.name: MINCE
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: certain equivalent value of expected utility

arguments.name: CSYMBOLC=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CSYMBOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all decision nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CSYMBOLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all end nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to be used for all text that appears on plots except on TITLE and FOOTNOTE lines.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies a descriptive string, up to 40 characters long, that appears in the description field of the master menu of PROC GREPLAY.

arguments.name: DISPLAY=
arguments.description: Specifies information that should be displayed on each link of the decision tree diagram. Valid keywords are: ALL All information listed in this table CR Cumulative rewards of outcomes on the path that leads to the successor of the link EV Evaluating value that can be expected from the successor of the link LINK Outcome name represented by the link P Probability of the outcome represented by the link R Instant reward of the outcome represented by the link STAGE Stage name of the successor of the link

arguments.name: DOANNOTATE
arguments.description: Specifies that the Annotate data set should be processed.

arguments.name: ERRHANDLE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the procedure should stop processing the current statement and wait for next statement or quit PROC DTREE when an error has been detected by the procedure.

arguments.name: DRAIN
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should stop processing the current statement and wait for next statement.

arguments.name: QUIT
arguments.description: Specifies to quit PROC DTREE when an error has been detected by the procedure.

arguments.name: FTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the font to be used for text on plots.

arguments.name: GOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the graphics catalog used to save the output produced by PROC DTREE for later replay.

arguments.name: GRAPHICS
arguments.description: Creates plots for a graphics device. To specify this option, you need to have SAS/GRAPH software licensed at your site. This is the default.

arguments.name: HSYMBOL=
arguments.description: Specifies that the height of symbols for all nodes in the decision tree diagram is h times the heights of symbols assigned by SAS/GRAPH software.

arguments.name: HTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies that the height for all text in plots (except that in TITLE and FOOTNOTE statements) be h times the height of the characters assigned by SAS/GRAPH software.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that receives a description of the areas of a graph and a link for each area.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: Specifies that the labels for information displayed on the decision tree diagram should be displayed.

arguments.name: LEGEND
arguments.description: Specifies that the default legend should be displayed.

arguments.name: LINEPRINTER
arguments.description: Creates plots of line-printer quality. If you do not specify this option, graphics plots are produced.

arguments.name: LINKA=
arguments.description: If the LINKA=i option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CI= option, the type specified with the LINE= option, and the thickness specified with the WIDTH= option in the ith generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links in the decision tree diagram, except those that indicate optimal decisions and those that are continued on subsequent pages.

arguments.name: LINKB=
arguments.description: If the LINKB=j option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CI= option, the type specified with the LINE= option, and the thickness specified with the WIDTH= option in the jth generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: LINKC=
arguments.description: If the LINKC=k option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the type specified with the LINE= option in the kth generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links in the decision tree diagram that are continued on subsequent pages.

arguments.name: LSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing all links in the decision tree diagram, except those that represent the optimal decisions and those that are continued on subsequent pages. Valid values for l are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LSTYLEB=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing the links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions. Valid values for l2 are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LSTYLEC=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing the links in the decision tree diagram that are continued on the next subsequent pages. Valid values for l3 are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness (width) used to draw all links in the decision tree diagram except those that represent the optimal decisions.

arguments.name: LWIDTHB=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness (width) used to draw the links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: MAXPREC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum decimal width (the precision) in which to format numerical values using w.d format.

arguments.name: MAXWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format numerical values (probabilities, rewards, cumulative rewards and evaluating values) using w.d format.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a descriptive string, up to 8 characters long, that appears in the name field of the master menu of PROC GREPLAY. The default is 'DTREE '.

arguments.name: NOANNOTATE
arguments.description: Specifies that the Annotate data set should not be processed.

arguments.name: NOCOMPRESS
arguments.description: Specifies that the decision tree diagram should not be drawn on one physical page.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: Specifies that the labels for information displayed on the decision tree diagram should not be displayed.

arguments.name: NOLEGEND
arguments.description: Specifies that the default legend should not be displayed.

arguments.name: NOPAGENUM
arguments.description: Specifies that the page numbers should not be displayed in the top right corner of each page of a multipage decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: NORC
arguments.description: Specifies that the links in the decision tree diagram should not be drawn with rounded corners or with rectangular corners.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should not rescale the probabilities of events for a given chance stage. This is the default.

arguments.name: NOSUMMARY
arguments.description: Specifies that an optimal decision summary should not be displayed each time the decision tree is evaluated.

arguments.name: NOWARNING
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should not display a warning message when

arguments.name: NWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format outcome names when displaying the decision tree diagrams. The value for this option must be no greater than 40; the default value is 32.

arguments.name: PAGENUM
arguments.description: Specifies that the page numbers should be displayed in the top right corner of each page of a multipage decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: PAYOFFS=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the evaluating values (payoffs, losses, utilities, and so on) for each state and action combination.

arguments.name: PROBIN=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the (conditional) probability specifications of outcomes. The PROBIN= SAS data set is required if the evaluation of the decision tree is desired.

arguments.name: RC
arguments.description: Specifies that the links in the decision tree diagram should be drawn with rounded corners or with rectangular corners.

arguments.name: RT=
arguments.description: Specifies the value of the risk tolerance.

arguments.name: STAGEIN=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the stage names, stage types, names of outcomes, and their rewards and successors for each stage.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Specifies that an optimal decision summary should be displayed each time the decision tree is evaluated.

arguments.name: SYMBOLC=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLC= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the mth generated SYMBOL definition to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: SYMBOLD=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLD= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the d-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all decision nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: SYMBOLE=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLE= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the n-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all end nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies the decision stage up to which the optimal decision policy table is displayed.

arguments.name: TOLERANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies either a positive number close to or greater than 1.

arguments.name: VSYMBOLC=
arguments.description: Specifies that the symbol symbolc-name from the special symbol table be used to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.
arguments.help: VSYMBOLC=PLUS | STAR | SQUARE | DIAMOND | HASH | PAW | POINT | DOT | CIRCLE | X | Y | Z

arguments.name: PLUS
arguments.description: + symbol

arguments.name: STAR
arguments.description: * symbol

arguments.description: Square symbol

arguments.description: Diamond

arguments.description: . . symbol

arguments.description: X symbol

arguments.name: Y
arguments.description: Y symbol

arguments.name: Z
arguments.description: Z symbol

arguments.name: VSYMBOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies that the symbol symbold-name from the special symbol table be used to draw all decision nodes in the decision tree diagram.
arguments.help: VSYMBOLD=PLUS | STAR | SQUARE | DIAMOND | HASH | PAW | POINT | DOT | CIRCLE | X | Y | Z

arguments.help: VSYMBOLE=PLUS | STAR | SQUARE | DIAMOND | HASH | PAW | POINT | DOT | CIRCLE | X | Y | Z

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should display a warning message when

arguments.name: YBETWEEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical distance between two successive end nodes.

statements.name: EVALUATE
statements.description: The EVALUATE statement causes PROC DTREE to evaluate the decision tree and calculate the optimal decisions. If the SUMMARY option is specified a decision summary is displayed. Otherwise, the current optimal value is displayed on the SAS log.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Indicates the decision criterion to be used for determining the optimal decision and the certain equivalent for replacing uncertainties.
arguments.help: CRITERION=MAXEV | MINEV | MAXMLV | MINMLV | MAXCE | MINCE

arguments.name: MAXEV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: expected value

arguments.name: MINEV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: expected value

arguments.name: MAXMLV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: value with largest probability

arguments.name: MINMLV
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: value with largest probability

arguments.name: MAXCE
arguments.description: Decision criterion: maximize; certain equivalent: certain equivalent value of expected utility

arguments.name: MINCE
arguments.description: Decision criterion: minimize; certain equivalent: certain equivalent value of expected utility

arguments.name: MAXPREC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum decimal width (the precision) in which to format numerical values using w.d format.

arguments.name: MAXWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format numerical values (probabilities, rewards, cumulative rewards and evaluating values) using w.d format.

arguments.name: NOSUMMARY
arguments.description: Specifies that an optimal decision summary should not be displayed each time the decision tree is evaluated.

arguments.name: NWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format outcome names when displaying the decision tree diagrams. The value for this option must be no greater than 40; the default value is 32.

arguments.name: RT=
arguments.description: Specifies the value of the risk tolerance.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Specifies that an optimal decision summary should be displayed each time the decision tree is evaluated.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies the decision stage up to which the optimal decision policy table is displayed.

statements.name: MODIFY
statements.description: The MODIFY statement is used to change either the type of a stage or the reward from an outcome. If MODIFY outcome-name REWARD new-value is given where the outcome-name is an outcome specified in the STAGEIN= data set, and new-value is a numeric value, then the reward of the outcome named outcome-name is changed to new-value. If MODIFY stage-name TYPE is given where stage-name is a stage name specified in the STAGEIN= data set, then the type of the stage named stage-name is changed to 'DECISION' if its current type is 'CHANCE' and is changed to 'CHANCE' if its current type is 'DECISION'. You cannot change the type of an 'END' stage. The change of the type of a stage from 'CHANCE' to 'DECISION' can help the decision- maker learn how much improvement can be expected if he or she could pick which of the future (or unknown) outcomes would occur. However, if you want to change the type of a stage from 'DECISION' to 'CHANCE', the procedure is not able to determine the probabilities for its outcomes unless you specify them in the PROBIN= data set.

arguments.name: REWARD
arguments.description: If MODIFY outcome-name REWARD new-value is given where the outcome-name is an outcome specified in the STAGEIN= data set, and new-value is a numeric value, then the reward of the outcome named outcome- name is changed to new-value.

arguments.name: TYPE
arguments.description: If MODIFY stage-name TYPE is given where stage-name is a stage name specified in the STAGEIN= data set, then the type of the stage named stage-name is changed to 'DECISION' if its current type is 'CHANCE' and is changed to 'CHANCE' if its current type is 'DECISION'. You cannot change the type of an 'END' stage. The change of the type of a stage from 'CHANCE' to 'DECISION' can help the decision- maker learn how much improvement can be expected if he or she could pick which of the future (or unknown) outcomes would occur. However, if you want to change the type of a stage from 'DECISION' to 'CHANCE', the procedure is not able to determine the probabilities for its outcomes unless you specify them in the PROBIN= data set.

statements.name: MOVE
statements.description: The MOVE statement is used to change the order of the stages. After all data in input data sets have been read, PROC DTREE determines the order (from left to right) of all stages specified in the STAGEIN= data set and display the order in the SAS log.

arguments.name: AFTER
arguments.description: If the keyword AFTER is used, the old leftmost (in previous order) successor of outcomes for stage2 becomes the new successor for all outcomes of stage1 and the new successor of all outcomes of stage2 is stage1.

arguments.name: BEFORE
arguments.description: If the keyword BEFORE is used, stage1 becomes the new successor for all immediate predecessors of stage2, and stage2 becomes the new successor for all outcomes of stage1. An outcome is said to be an immediate predecessor of a stage if the stage is the successor of that outcome.

statements.name: QUIT
statements.description: The QUIT statement tells the DTREE procedure to terminate processing. This statement has no options.

statements.name: RECALL
statements.description: This statement tells PROC DTREE to recall the decision model that was saved previously with a SAVE statement. The RECALL statement has no options.

statements.name: RESET
statements.description: The RESET statement is used to change options after the procedure has started. All of the options that can be set in the PROC DTREE statement can also be reset with this statement, except for the STAGEIN=, the PROBIN=, and the PAYOFFS= data set options.

arguments.name: FORMCHAR=
arguments.description: Defines characters to be used for features on line-printer plots. The syni-list is a list of numbers ranging from 1 to 13. The features associated with values of syni are:

arguments.help: VSYMBOLD=PLUS | STAR | SQUARE | DIAMOND | HASH | PAW | POINT | DOT | CIRCLE | X | Y | Z

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: Specifies that the procedure should display a warning message when

arguments.name: YBETWEEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical distance between two successive end nodes.

statements.name: SAVE
statements.description: The SAVE statement saves the current model (attributes of stages and outcomes, the ordering of stages, and so on) to a scratch space from which you can call it back later.

statements.name: SUMMARY
statements.description: Unlike the SUMMARY option on the PROC DTREE statement or the EVALUATE statement, which specifies that PROC DTREE display a decision summary when the decision tree is evaluated, the SUMMARY statement causes the procedure to display the summary immediately.

arguments.name: MAXPREC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum decimal width (the precision) in which to format numerical values using w.d format.

arguments.name: MAXWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format numerical values (probabilities, rewards, cumulative rewards and evaluating values) using w.d format.

arguments.name: NWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format outcome names when displaying the decision tree diagrams. The value for this option must be no greater than 40; the default value is 32.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies the decision stage up to which the optimal decision policy table is displayed.

statements.name: TREEPLOT
statements.description: The TREEPLOT statement plots the current decision tree (a diagram of the decision problem). Each path in the decision tree represents a possible scenario of the problem.

arguments.name: ANNOTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies an input data set that contains appropriate Annotate variables.

arguments.name: CBEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for all links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: CLINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the color for all links in the decision tree diagram except those that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: COMPRESS
arguments.description: Specifies that the decision tree diagram should be drawn on one physical page.

arguments.name: CSYMBOLC=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CSYMBOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all decision nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CSYMBOLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the color of the symbol used to draw all end nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the color to be used for all text that appears on plots except on TITLE and FOOTNOTE lines.

arguments.name: DESCRIPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies a descriptive string, up to 40 characters long, that appears in the description field of the master menu of PROC GREPLAY.

arguments.name: DISPLAY=
arguments.description: Specifies information that should be displayed on each link of the decision tree diagram. Valid keywords are: ALL All information listed in this table CR Cumulative rewards of outcomes on the path that leads to the successor of the link EV Evaluating value that can be expected from the successor of the link LINK Outcome name represented by the link P Probability of the outcome represented by the link R Instant reward of the outcome represented by the link STAGE Stage name of the successor of the link

arguments.name: DOANNOTATE
arguments.description: Specifies that the Annotate data set should be processed.

arguments.name: FORMCHAR=
arguments.description: Defines characters to be used for features on line-printer plots. The syni-list is a list of numbers ranging from 1 to 13. The features associated with values of syni are:

arguments.name: FTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the font to be used for text on plots.

arguments.name: GOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the graphics catalog used to save the output produced by PROC DTREE for later replay.

arguments.name: GRAPHICS
arguments.description: Creates plots for a graphics device. To specify this option, you need to have SAS/GRAPH software licensed at your site. This is the default.

arguments.name: HSYMBOL=
arguments.description: Specifies that the height of symbols for all nodes in the decision tree diagram is h times the heights of symbols assigned by SAS/GRAPH software.

arguments.name: HTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies that the height for all text in plots (except that in TITLE and FOOTNOTE statements) be h times the height of the characters assigned by SAS/GRAPH software.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that receives a description of the areas of a graph and a link for each area.

arguments.name: LABEL
arguments.description: Specifies that the labels for information displayed on the decision tree diagram should be displayed.

arguments.name: LEGEND
arguments.description: Specifies that the default legend should be displayed.

arguments.name: LINEPRINTER
arguments.description: Creates plots of line-printer quality. If you do not specify this option, graphics plots are produced.

arguments.name: LINKA=
arguments.description: If the LINKA=i option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CI= option, the type specified with the LINE= option, and the thickness specified with the WIDTH= option in the ith generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links in the decision tree diagram, except those that indicate optimal decisions and those that are continued on subsequent pages.

arguments.name: LINKB=
arguments.description: If the LINKB=j option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CI= option, the type specified with the LINE= option, and the thickness specified with the WIDTH= option in the j-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: LINKC=
arguments.description: If the LINKC=k option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the type specified with the LINE= option in the k-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all links in the decision tree diagram that are continued on subsequent pages.

arguments.name: LSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing all links in the decision tree diagram, except those that represent the optimal decisions and those that are continued on subsequent pages. Valid values for l are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LSTYLEB=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing the links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions. Valid values for l2 are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LSTYLEC=
arguments.description: Specifies the line type (style) used for drawing the links in the decision tree diagram that are continued on the next subsequent pages. Valid values for l3 are 1 though 46.

arguments.name: LWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness (width) used to draw all links in the decision tree diagram except those that represent the optimal decisions.

arguments.name: LWIDTHB=
arguments.description: Specifies the line thickness (width) used to draw the links in the decision tree diagram that represent optimal decisions.

arguments.name: MAXPREC=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum decimal width (the precision) in which to format numerical values using w.d format.

arguments.name: MAXWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format numerical values (probabilities, rewards, cumulative rewards and evaluating values) using w.d format.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Specifies a descriptive string, up to 8 characters long, that appears in the name field of the master menu of PROC GREPLAY. The default is 'DTREE '.

arguments.name: NOANNOTATE
arguments.description: Specifies that the Annotate data set should not be processed.

arguments.name: NOCOMPRESS
arguments.description: Specifies that the decision tree diagram should not be drawn on one physical page.

arguments.name: NOLABEL
arguments.description: Specifies that the labels for information displayed on the decision tree diagram should not be displayed.

arguments.name: NOLEGEND
arguments.description: Specifies that the default legend should not be displayed.

arguments.name: NOPAGENUM
arguments.description: Specifies that the page numbers should not be displayed in the top right corner of each page of a multipage decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: NORC
arguments.description: Specifies that the links in the decision tree diagram should not be drawn with rounded corners or with rectangular corners.

arguments.name: NWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum field width in which to format outcome names when displaying the decision tree diagrams. The value for this option must be no greater than 40; the default value is 32.

arguments.name: PAGENUM
arguments.description: Specifies that the page numbers should be displayed in the top right corner of each page of a multipage decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: RC
arguments.description: Specifies that the links in the decision tree diagram should be drawn with rounded corners or with rectangular corners.

arguments.name: SYMBOLC=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLC= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the m-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: SYMBOLD=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLD= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the d-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all decision nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: SYMBOLE=
arguments.description: If the SYMBOLE= option is specified, then PROC DTREE uses the color specified with the CV= option, the character specified with the VALUE= option, the font specified with the FONT= option, and the height specified with the HEIGHT= option in the n-th generated SYMBOL definition to draw all end nodes in the decision tree diagram.

arguments.name: VSYMBOLC=
arguments.description: Specifies that the symbol symbolc-name from the special symbol table be used to draw all chance nodes in the decision tree diagram.
arguments.help: VSYMBOLC=PLUS | STAR | SQUARE | DIAMOND | HASH | PAW | POINT | DOT | CIRCLE | X | Y | Z

arguments.name: YBETWEEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the vertical distance between two successive end nodes.

statements.name: VARIABLES
statements.description: The VARIABLES statement specifies the variable lists in the input data sets. This statement is optional but if it is used, it must appear immediately after the PROC DTREE statement.

arguments.name: ACTION=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PAYOFFS= data set that contain the name of the final outcome for each possible scenario.

arguments.name: COST=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the STAGEIN= data set that contain the reward for each outcome specified by the OUTCOME= variables.

arguments.name: EVENT=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PROBIN= data set that contain the names of events (outcomes) that probabilities depend on the outcomes specified by the GIVEN= variables.

arguments.name: GIVEN=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PROBIN= data set that contain the given condition (a list of outcome names)of a chance stage on which the probabilities of the outcome depend.

arguments.name: OUTCOME=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the STAGEIN= data set that contain the outcome names of the stage specified by the STAGE= variable.

arguments.name: PROB=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PROBIN= data set that contain the values of the conditional probability of each event specified by the EVENT= variables, given that the outcomes specified by the GIVEN= variables have occurred.

arguments.name: REWARD=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the STAGEIN= data set that contain the reward for each outcome specified by the OUTCOME= variables.

arguments.name: STAGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the variable in the STAGEIN= data set that names the stages in the decision model.

arguments.name: STATE=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PAYOFFS= data set that contain the names of outcomes that identify a possible scenario (a sequence of outcomes or a path in the decision tree), or the names of outcomes which combine with every outcome specified by the ACTION= variables to identify a possible scenario.

arguments.name: SUCCESSOR=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the STAGEIN= data set that contain the names of immediate successors (another stage) of each outcome specified by the OUTCOME= variables. These variables must be of the same type and length as those defined in the STAGE= option.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Identifies the variable in the STAGEIN= data set that contains the type identifier of the stage specified by the STAGE= variable.

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: Identifies all variables in the PAYOFFS= data set that contain the evaluating values or payoffs for all possible scenarios identified by the outcomes specified by the STATE= variables and the outcomes specified by the associated ACTION= variables.

arguments.name: WEB=
arguments.description: Specifies the character variable in the STAGEIN= data set that identifies an HTML page for each stage.

statements.name: VPC
statements.description: The VPC statement causes PROC TREE to compute the value of perfect control (the value of controlling an uncertainty). The effect of perfect control is that you can pick the outcome of an uncertain stage. This value gives an upper limit on the amount you should be willing to spend on any control procedure.

statements.name: VPI
statements.description: The VPI statement causes PROC DTREE to compute the value of perfect information. The value of perfect information is the benefit of resolving an uncertain stage before making a decision. This value is the upper limit on the improvement that can be expected for any information gathering effort.
